text: today I consider myself the luckiest man
on the face of the earth Alaniz got a
story today about Lou Gehrig's disease
and some new research that has led to
some interesting conclusions and some
new distinctions Lou Gehrig of course
had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and
that disease now is called Lou Gehrig's
disease but it now appears because a
group at Boston University the same
group that has studied dementia and
other brain disease type things in
football players they have found that in
three cases of men who were diagnosed
with ALS they in fact did not have ALS
they had something that was a result of
brain trauma what that means for Lou
Gehrig who had a very significant
history of concussions on the baseball
field he was also a very high level
bulldozer fullback for Columbia
University and commerce high here in
Manhattan it's possible because of the
number of times his brain was injured
that he didn't have ALS just like these
football players he might have had
something else now we'll never know
because his remains were cremated which
are now buried in Valhalla New York in
other words what we're saying is that
rather than just being the fate of God
that in fact he may have obviously
inadvertently brought this on himself
and I think that's the the important
thing going forward for current athletes
right absolutely I mean what we've
learned is that concussions and other
brain trauma are extraordinarily
dangerous when not handled properly now
in Lou Gehrig's time they didn't know
this is a very rare disease and this is
a very rare subset of people who have
the disease nonetheless it's yet another
indication that the things that we
hailed Lou Gehrig for playing through
pain might have been more dangerous than
we thought
